ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned more about how to engage with conversations and readings about how Latinx students interact with the U.S. education system. I also learned how to write opinion articles and policy briefs about a variety of education-related topics.

This was a really great overview of the formation of the current state of Latinx identity and community formation with historical context, and how that situates itself in the current landscape of U.S. education.
I learned SO MUCH about Latinidad, its nuances and manifestations in U.S education! In terms of concrete skills, we also learned how to write policy briefs.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: great diversity of topics/readings on the syllabus, strong class organization (google documents, groupwork sessions, large group discussions, small projects)
Weaknesses: None that I can really think of.

The readings and other media we were assigned each week were really well selected to give a range of perspectives and illuminate the topics we were studying. Professor Cordova-Cobos lecture style and slides were also really helpful for me during each class before we began discussion. I do think that the final paper was a bit intense for the level of this course, but we were also given a lot of time to prepare for it.

Strengths: great prof and interesting material! I learned a lot, and the day to day classes had a really good balance of lecture and structured discussion.
Cons: TONS of writing that I didnt always feel fully prepared for

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yess especially if interested in understanding Latinidad more and how that relates to education

Yes! This course not only gave me a better understanding of a wide range of educational topics, it also taught me so much about Latinx students and families in particular. The intersectionality of this course really made it valuable to me, as we could talk about race, ethnicity, education, gender, class and immigration in a single setting.

Yes, it is a lot of work but it is a really thorough and insightful class. You really learn as much about the racial and ethnic formation of Latinidad in the U.S. as you do about the current state of education, which is really helpful for anyone interested in either of those general areas. Professor Cordova-Cobo also does a great job of guiding us through the course material.
Yes 1000%! I learned a lot and was challenged but not in an unreasonable way.
